holdings.reasoning_summary: Cloth Association contravened s.4(2) Rewa State Companies Act as unregistered association of 25 members for business gain; illegal partnership contract; members have no remedy against each other for accounts or contribution.

holdings.text: In our view, the same principle applies in the present case and s. 4 2  of the Rewa State Companies Act, 1935, being prohibitory in nature cannot be excluded from consideration even though the bar of that provision has been raised at this late stage.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the same principle applies in the present case and s. 4 2  of the Rewa State Companies Act, 1935, being prohibitory in nature cannot be excluded from consideration even though the bar of that provision has been raised at this late stage. On his second contention learned counsel for the appellants has relied on U. Sein Po v. U. Phyu 2 . That was a case in which three members of an association formed for carrying on a rice business claimed a decree declaring the respective shares of the subscribers to that association and directing that the plaintiffs be repaid their shares after reconverting the property of the association into cash and after payment of all debts and liabilities.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Objection based on public prohibitory statute; pure question of law; no need for facts investigation; follows Surajmull v. Triton and Shiba Prasad Singh; can be raised at any stage including Supreme Court.

holdings.text: The case before us stands on a different footing. It is a claim by some members of an illegal association against another member on the footing that the association should be treated as legal in order to give rise to a liability to render accounts in respect of the transactions of the association. Such a claim is clearly untenable.

anchor.surface_text: The case before us stands on a different footing. It is a claim by some members of an illegal association against another member on the footing that the association should be treated as legal in order to give rise to a liability to render accounts in respect of the transac- tions of the association. Such a claim is clearly unten- able. Where a plaintiff comes to court on allegations which on the face of them show that the contract of partnership on which he sues is illegal, the only course for the courts to pursue is to say that he is not entitled to any relief on the allegations made as the courts cannot adjudicate in respect of contracts which the law declares to be illegal  Senaji Kapurchand v. Pannaji Devichand 2  .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes U. Sein Po (refund subscriptions, prevent continuance of illegal); here suit enforces illegal contract by demanding accounts and profits share; follows Lindley on Partnership and Senaji Kapurchand.

holdings.text: We do not think that the argument by analogy is of any help to the appellants in our opinion, the analogy does not really apply.

anchor.surface_text: As to the last contention of learned counsel for the appellants, based on the analogy of s. 69 3  a  of the Partnership Act, it is enough to point out that under the Indian Partnership Act, 1932, an unregistered firm is not illegal there is no direct compulsion that a partnership firm must be registered, though the disabilities consequent on non-registration may be extremely inconvenient. Moreover, the suit before us was not one for accounts of a dissolved firm, but for accounts of an illegal association which was in existence at the relevant period for which accounts were asked. We do not think that the argument by analogy is of any help to the appellants in our opinion, the analogy does not really apply.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unregistered firm under Partnership Act not illegal unlike violation of Companies Act; suit not for dissolved firm accounts but illegal association transactions.

holdings.text: Admittedly, more than twenty persons formed the Association in question and it is not disputed that it was formed in contravention of s. 4 2  of the Rewa State Companies Act, 1935.

anchor.surface_text: The question is a pure question of law and does not require the investigation of any facts. Admittedly, more than twenty persons formed the Association in question and it is not disputed that it was formed in contravention of s. 4 2  of the Rewa State Companies Act, 1935. A similar question arose for consideration in Surajmull Nargoremull v. Triton Insurance Company Ltd. 1 . In that case sub-s. 1  of s. 7 of the Indian Stamp Act  11 of 1899  was pleaded as a bar before their Lordships of the Privy Council, the section not having been pleaded earlier and having passed unnoticed in the judgments of the courts below.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellants conceded provision in force; 25 members contributed capital, no registration, for profit business.

precedents.citation: Surajmull Nargoremull v. Triton Insurance Company Ltd. 1 1924 L.R. 52 I.A. 126, 128

anchor.surface_text: A similar question arose for consideration in Surajmull Nargoremull v. Triton Insurance Company Ltd. 1 . In that case sub-s. 1 of s. 7 of the Indian Stamp Act 11 of 1899 was pleaded as a bar before their Lordships of the Privy Council, the section not having been pleaded earlier and having passed unnoticed in the judgments of the courts below. At p. 128 of the report Lord Sumner said, , The suggestion may be at once dismissed that it is too late not to raise the section as an answer to the claim. No court can enforce as valid that which competent enactments have declared shall not be valid, nor is obedience to such an enactment a thing from which a court can be dispensed by the consent of the parties, or by a failure to plead or to argue the point at the outset Nixon v. Alibion Marine Insurance Co., 1867 L. R. 2 Ex. 338.

precedents.case_name: Surajmull Nargoremull v. Triton Insurance Company Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: It is not too late to raise a point based on a prohibitory public statute even if not raised in lower courts
precedents.cited_holding: No court can enforce as valid that which competent enactments have declared shall not be valid

precedents.citation: Nixon v. Alibion Marine Insurance Co., 1867 L. R. 2 Ex. 338

anchor.surface_text: the point at the outset Nixon v. Alibion Marine Insurance Co., 1867 L. R. 2 Ex. 338. The enactment is prohibitory. It is not confined to affording a party a protection, of which he may avail himself or not as he pleases . In Sri Sri Shiba Prasad Singh v. Maharaja Srish Chandra Nandi 1 , the provisions of s. 72 of the Indian Contract Act were overlooked by the High Court the section was only mentioned in passing by the Subordinate Judge and it appears that the bar of s. 72 of the Indian Contract Act was not argued or only faintly argued before the Subordinate Judge or in the High Court.

precedents.case_name: Nixon v. Albion Marine Insurance Co.
precedents.cited_proposition: Cited in support of principle that prohibitory enactments cannot be waived

precedents.citation: Sri Sri Shiba Prasad Singh v. Maharaja Srish Chandra Nandi 1 1949 L.R. 76 I.A. 244

anchor.surface_text: In Sri Sri Shiba Prasad Singh v. Maharaja Srish Chandra Nandi 1 , the provisions of s. 72 of the Indian Contract Act were overlooked by the High Court the section was only mentioned in passing by the Subordinate Judge and it appears that the bar of s. 72 of the Indian Contract Act was not argued or only faintly argued before the Subordinate Judge or in the High Court. In these circumstances, their Lordships of the Privy Council held that they were unable to exclude from their consideration the provisions of a public statute.

precedents.case_name: Sri Sri Shiba Prasad Singh v. Maharaja Srish Chandra Nandi
precedents.cited_proposition: Provisions of public statute cannot be excluded even if not argued earlier
precedents.cited_holding: Unable to exclude from consideration the provisions of a public statute

precedents.citation: U. Sein Po v. U. Phyu 2 1929 I.L.R. 7 Ran. 540

anchor.surface_text: On his second contention learned counsel for the appellants has relied on U. Sein Po v. U. Phyu 2 . That was a case in which three members of an association formed for carrying on a rice business claimed a decree declaring the respective shares of the subscribers to that association and directing that the plaintiffs be repaid their shares after reconverting the property of the association into cash and after payment of all debts and liabilities.

precedents.case_name: U. Sein Po v. U. Phyu

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges referred to the decision in Sheppard v. Oxenford 3 and Butt v. Monteaux 4 , and rested their decision on the following passage of Lindley on Partnership the learned Judges quoted the passage at p. 145 of the 9th edition but the same passage will be found at pp. 148-149 of the 11th edition Although, therefore, the subscribers to an illegal company have no a right to an account of the dealings and transactions of the company and of the profits made thereby, they have a right to have their subscriptions returned

precedents.cited_proposition: Referenced in context of returning subscriptions in illegal companies

precedents.citation: Butt v. Monteaux 4 1854 1 K. J. 98 69 E.R. 345

anchor.surface_text: Sheppard v. Oxenford 3 and Butt v. Monteaux 4 , and rested their decision on the following passage of Lindley on Partnership ... Although, therefore, the subscribers to an illegal company have no a right to an account of the dealings and transactions of the company and of the profits made thereby, they have a right to have their subscriptions returned and the necessary account taken and even though the moneys subscribed have been laid out in the purchase of land and other things for the purpose of the company the subscribers are entitled to have that land and those things reconverted into money,

precedents.cited_proposition: Referenced in context of returning subscriptions in illegal companies

anchor.surface_text: If money is paid by A to B to be applied by him for some illegal purpose, it is competent-for A to require B to hand back the money if B has not already parted with it and the illegal purpose has not been carried out see Greenberg v. Cooperstein 1 . The case before us stands on a different footing.

precedents.cited_proposition: Money paid for illegal purpose can be recovered if purpose not carried out

precedents.citation: Senaji Kapurchand v. Pannaji Devichand 2 A.I.R. 1930 P.C. 300

anchor.surface_text: Where a plaintiff comes to court on allegations which on the face of them show that the contract of partnership on which he sues is illegal, the only course for the courts to pursue is to say that he is not entitled to any relief on the allegations made as the courts cannot adjudicate in respect of contracts which the law declares to be illegal Senaji Kapurchand v. Pannaji Devichand 2 .

precedents.cited_proposition: No relief if suit based on allegations showing illegal contract
precedents.cited_holding: Courts cannot adjudicate in respect of contracts which the law declares to be illegal

anchor.surface_text: The same view, which we think is correct, was expressed in Kumaraswami v. Chinnathambi 1 . As to the last contention of learned counsel for the appellants, based on the analogy of s. 69 (3) (a) of the Partnership Act, it is enough to point out that under the Indian Partnership Act, 1932, an unregistered firm is not illegal there is no direct compulsion that a partnership firm must be registered, though the disabilities consequent on non-registration may be extremely inconvenient.

precedents.cited_proposition: Expresses the same view on no remedy for illegal partnership contracts

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the same principle applies in the present case and s. 4 2  of the Rewa State Companies Act, 1935, being prohibitory in nature cannot be excluded from consideration even though the bar of that provision has been raised at this late stage. On his second contention learned counsel for the appellants has relied on U. Sein Po v. U. Phyu 2 . That was a case in which three members of an association formed for carrying on a rice business claimed a decree declaring the respective shares of the subscribers to that association and directing that the plaintiffs be repaid their shares after reconverting the property of the association into cash and after payment of all debts and liabilities.
As we are of the opinion that the preliminary objection must succeed, it is necessary to state the facts only in so far as they have a bearing on it.

anchor.surface_text: The case before us stands on a different footing. It is a claim by some members of an illegal association against another member on the footing that the association should be treated as legal in order to give rise to a liability to render accounts in respect of the transac- tions of the association. Such a claim is clearly unten- able. Where a plaintiff comes to court on allegations which on the face of them show that the contract of partnership on which he sues is illegal, the only course for the courts to pursue is to say that he is not entitled to any relief on the allegations made as the courts cannot adjudicate in respect of contracts which the law declares to be illegal  Senaji Kapurchand v. Pannaji Devichand 2  .
As we are of the opinion that the preliminary objection must succeed, it is necessary to state the facts only in so far as they have a bearing on it.

anchor.surface_text: As to the last contention of learned counsel for the appellants, based on the analogy of s. 69 3  a  of the Partnership Act, it is enough to point out that under the Indian Partnership Act, 1932, an unregistered firm is not illegal there is no direct compulsion that a partnership firm must be registered, though the disabilities consequent on non-registration may be extremely inconvenient. Moreover, the suit before us was not one for accounts of a dissolved firm, but for accounts of an illegal association which was in existence at the relevant period for which accounts were asked. We do not think that the argument by analogy is of any help to the appellants in our opinion, the analogy does not really apply.
As we are of the opinion that the preliminary objection must succeed, it is necessary to state the facts only in so far as they have a bearing on it.
As we are of the opinion that the preliminary objection must succeed, it is necessary to state the facts only in so far as they have a bearing on it.
